[[Cinnamon (comics)|Cinnamon]] | aliases = [[Hawkman]] | supports= | powers = Repair skills, expert marksman and horseman }} '''Nighthawk''' is a [[fictional character]], a [[cowboy]] in the [[DC Comics]] [[DC Universe|universe]]. His real name is '''Hannibal Hawkes''' and he first appeared in ''[[Western Comics]]'' #5. In his [[secret identity]], he worked as a traveling repairman. He had a [[sidekick]] named Jim Peyton. Created by Joe Millard and [[Charles Paris]],{{cite web|author= |url=https://www.comics.org/issue/6959/ |title= ''Western Comics'' #5 |publisher=Grand Comics Database |date= |accessdate=2018-06-24}} his later adventures were handled by writers [[France Herron]], [[Donald Clough Cameron|Don Cameron]], and [[Gardner Fox]]; and artists [[Gil Kane]] and [[Carmine Infantino]].Markstein, Don. [http://www.toonopedia.com/nighthwk.htm "Nighthawk"], Don Markstein's Toonopedia. Accessed Aug. 13, 2011. ==Fictional character biography== He was shown as dying during ''[[Crisis on Infinite Earths]]'',''Crisis on Infinite Earths'' #3 (June 1985). although this has been [[retcon]]ned twice to fit in with the later revelation that he was a [[reincarnation]] of Prince Khufu — who would later be reincarnated as [[Carter Hall (comics)|Carter Hall]], the [[Golden Age of Comic Books|Golden Age]] [[Hawkman]]. Current continuity has it that he was shot by a criminal named Matilda Roderic,''Hawkman'' (vol. 4) #7 (Nov 2002) who was presumably a reincarnation of the evil priest [[Hath-Set]], who is apparently destined to kill Khufu in every life. Roderic's descendant is the current Hath-Set. The 2002 retcon also revealed he was the partner and lover of the Western heroine [[Cinnamon (comics)|Cinnamon]], who was the reincarnation of Khufu's wife [[Hawkgirl#Shiera Sanders|Chay-Ara]]. Nighthawk appears in [[Guy Gardner (comics)|''Guy Gardner'']] #24''Guy Gardner: Warrior'' #24 (September 1994). during the ''[[Zero Hour (comics)|Zero Hour]]'' incident. He sported white sideburns at this point in time. His group of allies, which includes El Diablo and [[Bat Lash]], were forming to take on the villain Extant and several men Extant had brainwashed. Nighthawk calls this group the "Rough Bunch" on more than one occasion. The time-lost heroes [[Steel (comics)|Steel]], Supergirl, Guy Gardner and a version of [[Batgirl]] show up to help in the fight. A modern-day version of the character appears in the Western-themed ''Robin'' (vol. 2) Annual #6,''Robin'' (vol. 2) Annual #6 (1997). as a mercenary. He worked with [[Robin (Tim Drake)|Robin]] and the modern day [[Pow Wow Smith]] to track down the modern day [[Trigger Twins]]. They have a literal Main Street showdown in a Western-themed tourist attraction located near [[Gotham City]]. ===The New 52=== Nighthawk appears in ''All Star Western'' in both its backups and in the main Jonah Hex story.{{cite book |last1=Cowsill |first1=Alan |last2=Irvine |first2=Alex |last3=Korte |first3=Steve |last4=Manning |first4=Matt |last5=Wiacek |first5=Win |last6=Wilson |first6=Sven |title=The DC Comics Encyclopedia: The Definitive Guide to the Characters of the DC Universe |date=2016 |publisher=DK Publishing |isbn=978-1-4654-5357-0 |page=351}} Nighthawk's new origin is that he left home as a child and worked on a whaling boat. The captain, a former slave, became a second father to him and Nighthawk was there when the man died. This death inspired Nighthawk to fight for justice and for the oppressed. Nighthawk is teamed with [[Cinnamon (comics)|Cinnamon]] once again. Nighthawk uses a special medallion he found at an Indian burial site which gives him enhanced strength and healing abilities. ==In other media== ===Television=== * In ''[[The Flash (2014 TV series)|The Flash]]'' episode [[List of The Flash (2014 TV series) episodes#ep7|"Power Outage"]], a movie poster can be seen featuring Nighthawk and Cinnamon. * In the ''[[Legends of Tomorrow|DC's Legends of Tomorrow]]'' episode "[[Legends of Tomorrow#Episodes|The Magnificent Eight]]", present Hawkgirl meets her previous incarnation [[Cinnamon (comics)|Cinnamon]] in 1871, who discusses her sorrow over the death of her husband, Hannibal Hawkes / '''[[Hawkman]]'''. ===Other=== * French-Canadian electro-rock band Judge Rock has him as a character in their 2012 song ''Westerner'', depicting scenes from the 1985/86 ''[[Crisis on Infinite Earths]]'' comics series where Nighthawk appears: "Then came Nighthawk, the sombre man / White bird on a dark shirt / Hand on his gun, boots in the dirt / He was the gravest of the clan". ==References== {{reflist}} {{DC Western Characters}} [[Category:Comics characters introduced in 1948]] [[Category:DC Comics Western (genre) characters]] [[Category:DC Comics characters with accelerated healing]] [[Category:Fictional gunfighters]] [[Category:Fictional mercenaries in comics]] [[Category:Golden Age adventure heroes]] [[Category:DC Comics male characters]]
